newsitem.title: UK: ASDA aims for bigger slice of book market.
newsitem.headline: ASDA aims for bigger slice of book market.

text.p: British supermarket chain ASDA Plc said on Monday that it was taking steps to secure a bigger slice of the books market for its 212 stores.
In a statement, the company said that it would increase its range of titles and control ordering and discounting with deals negotiated directly with publishers.
"It means ASDA will be able to offer even more books to customers at low prices," the company said.
ASDA was a leading force in breaking the Net Book Agreement which allowed publishers to set book prices.
ASDA sold seven million books in 1996, up 40 percent on the year earlier.
"We believe we can grow our books business substantially and grab some serious market share," said ASDA's books manager Julian Graham-Rack.
ASDA said it will be targeting paperback fiction, children's books and cookery titles.
A series of initiatives on books and pricing will be made in the coming months, the company said.
